Isabel es de tez morena, ojos pardos, cabello negro largo lo usa amarrado, baja estatura, complexión física robusta, su lengua materna es el Guaraní que habla en familia y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza (de pie, la segunda de la izquierda, viste polera a rayas verticales). Su vida la comparte con su pareja que se dedica a la construcción y con su hijo que estudia en la escuela, viven en un cuarto propio construido de ladrillo y cemento con techo de calamina que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. Los deseos de mejorar su negocio la llevaron a formar una banca de personas con negocios como; venta de champú, venta de pañales, venta de comida, venta de ropa de segunda mano, venta de masitas, servicio de transporte y venta de blusas juveniles, para solicitar un préstamo y mejorar sus actividades. Su negocio es la venta de frutas, como; plátanos, manzanas, papayas, naranjas, piñas, etc. Actividad que realiza durante el día en su puesto fijo de venta de lunes a domingo. Como segunda actividad se encarga de la venta de desayuno, sus clientes son comerciantes que no pueden abandonar sus puestos de venta, y ella les entrega el desayuno en su lugar de trabajo. “inicié mi negocio vendiendo frutas, luego mis compañeros del comercio me pidieron que les ayude sirviéndoles desayuno, ambas actividades ocupan todo mi tiempo…” comenta. La ventaja de sus actividades es que cuenta con una cartera de clientes diarios, la desventaja es la competencia con mejores precios. Su sueño es abrir un kiosco para vender desayuno, ella desea ampliar su negocio mediante la compra de fruta por camionada para abrir un kiosco de desayuno. Esta es la 2 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 1 año que desarrolla esta actividad de forma contínua.
Es por esos motivos que Isabel solicita un préstamo para la compra de frutas por mayor y con los beneficios abrir un kiosco para la venta de desayunos.
texts.en:
Isabel is a 30-year-old woman who lives with her partner and has a 12-year-old son. Her business is selling fruit.

She is a good mother: patient, entrepreneurial, independent, responsible, and very hard-working. She developed her business in the "Plan 3000" zone, which is characterized by enormous commercial growth, a lot of manufacturing, its population originating from the "Ayoreas" tribes and the miners who relocated from the western side of the country, and by its subtropical climate with daytime temperatures between 21-35 degrees Celsius.

Isabel has a dark complexion, brown eyes, long black hair, usually tied back, short stature and robust physique. Her native language is Guaraní, which she speaks with her family, and she speaks Spanish in general and when she is at work. In the picture, Isabel is standing, the second from the left, wearing a shirt with vertical stripes.

She shares her life with her partner, who makes a living in construction, and with her son, who studies at school. The live in their own home, made out of wood and cement with a metal roof, with potable water, electricity, and a sewage system.

The desire to improve her business led her to form a bank with other people with businesses to request a loan and improve their business activity. The other business include: selling shampoo, selling panels, selling food, selling second-hand clothing, selling cakes, selling blouses, and transportation service.

Isabel's business is selling fruit, such as plantains, apples, papayas, oranges, pineapples, etc. She does this in a fixed location during the day from Monday to Sunday. As a second business, she sells breakfast to other merchants who can't leave their posts so she delivers the breakfast to their places of work. Says Isabel, "I began my business selling fruits. Later, my business companions asked me to help them by serving breakfast. Both activities occupy all my time." The advantage of her businesses is that she counts on a lot of daily customers. The disadvantage is that there is competition with better prices.

Isabel's dream is to open a kiosk to sell breakfast. She wants to expand her business through the bulk purchase of fruits from the trucks in order to open a breakfast kiosk. The is the second loan from the institution that helps her continually develop her business. It is for these motivations that Isabel is requesting a loan to purchase bulk quantities of fruit and use the profit to open a kiosk for breakfast sales.

loans.use: to purchase a large quantity of fruit and use the profit to open a kiosk to sell breakfast food.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy snack foods including fish balls, kikiam, hot dogs, pancit, banana cue, and juice to sell

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses is a young farmer from the Nkubu area of Kenya who is seeking funds to buy a beef cow. He has been in Kenya's meat industry for more than 10 years and, on his father's 1.5 acre farm, raises cattle, poultry, pigs and goats in order to sell their meat. Moses has requested a loan from Kiva lenders to buy a beef cow that he will raise and later sell for meat in order to make a profit. Money from this investment will allow him to expand the horticultural section of his farm, where he grows maize, beans and tobacco.

loans.use: to buy a beef cow.

loans.name: Salina

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Salina, 45 years old, married and blessed with three children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2013 and she learned more skills on enterprise development and financial management. This helped her improve her knowledge in business management.

Salina has been doing dairy farming for the past two years. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy fodder for her cows and to start a poultry business. This will help her provide for the family by meeting basic family needs.

Salina appreciates Kiva and their lenders for the support and help and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy fodder that will that will improve milk production and buy chickens to start poultry farming.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Lina is a 29-year-old, mother with three children. She is a Samoan citizen, and runs a business of selling rice and curry at the market to earn a living.  Lina needs a loan to buy a sack of flour, box of curry, box of chicken, sack of rice, bottle of vegetable oil, gas stove, and sack of onions to help her run the business. She will use her profits to build a restaurant in the near future. She became a member of SPBD in 2014.

loans.use: to buy a sack of flour, box of curry, box of chicken, sack of rice, bottle of vegetable oil, gas stove, and sack of onions.

loans.name: Maria Antonia

texts.es: María de 48 años de edad vive en casa propia con su grupo familiar, ella se dedica a la agricultura al cultivo de maíz, tiene 15 años de experiencia en el cultivo el cual inicio con capital propio, cuando su cosecha ya esta lista la almacena en sacos así como muestra la fotografía para luego comercializarlas en los alrededores de la zona donde el reside, con lo que obtiene de sus ventas logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, ella está solicitando un crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, abonos, controles de plagas, herbicidas, etc. para continuar con sus cultivos y así tener mejores ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
María is 48 years old and lives in her own home with her family group. She makes a living in agriculture, through the cultivation of maize. She has 15 years of experience in cultivating maize, which she began with her own capital.

When her crop is ready, she stores it in sacks, as is shown in the photograph, so that she can later sell it around the area where she lives. With the revenue from her sales, she is able to take care of some of her home expenses.

She is requesting a loan for the purchase of seeds, fertilizers, pest control, herbicide, etc. to continue her cultivation and have higher earnings.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, pest control, herbicide, etc.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Miriam, 32, has a mixed-use farm where she is based with her family in Kapsowar in the North Rift region of Kenya. On the farm, she grows various crops and keeps dairy cattle and poultry.

For the last six years, she has made money selling her farm's produce and engaging in other side businesses. She feels passionate about farming. However, her business is facing challenges such as the high cost of inputs and occasional drought.

Miriam is seeking a loan to purchase poultry. The upside, to Miriam, of focusing more on her poultry business, is that it is less affected by the major challenges that face her other farm activities. Poultry feed is readily available. The hens also lay eggs regardless of the season of the year. This investment will provide a certain source of income all year round.

The money Miriam will make from this expansion will cater to her family expenses such as food and school fees. She wants her family to enjoy a balanced diet to grow strong and healthy so that they can be more productive towards generating income for the family.

loans.use: to buy poultry

loans.name: Haron

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photo is Haron, 44 years old, married, and he has seven children. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013. He does maize and beans farming as his economic activity, which has helped him to meet part of his family’s needs. 

Since the time he joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa, Haron has gained skills on how to manage and run his enterprise well. He is borrowing from Kiva to buy farm inputs such as fertilizers and seeds in order to improve the crop yield.  Thus, his income will increase and he will be in a position to cater for his children’s education, clothing, and food.  He is grateful for kiva and their lenders and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as fertilizer and seeds to help boost farming.

loans.name: Roberto Carlos

texts.es: Roberto, tiene 27 años de edad, esta casado, tiene un hijo y reside en una aldea del municipio del Progreso, Yoro. Hace mas de 5 años que inició su propio negocio de barbería donde corta cabello, cejas y barba. Además su esposa vende golosinas para obtener otros ingresos. esta actividad la realiza en su casa. Roberto ha decidido solicitar un préstamo por 20,000 Lempiras, para comprar e instalar un aire acondicionado en su barbería. El piensa que al tener climatizado el salón va tener mas clientes. Tiene planeado ampliar  el local y poner venta de licuados y con las ganancias obtenidas piensa comprar una vivienda.
texts.en:
Roberto is 27 years old, married, has a son, and lives in a small, unincorporated community in the municipality of Progreso, Yoro. Over five years ago, he began his own barber shop business where he cuts hair, eyebrows, and beards. Also, his wife sells candy to have another income; she runs this business from the home.

Roberto has decided to request a loan for HNL 20,000 to purchase and install an air conditioning unit in his barber shop. He thinks that when he has an air-conditioned shop, he will have more customers. He has planned to expand his storefront and add smoothie sales. With the earnings, he plans to purchase a home.

loans.use: to purchase and install air conditioning for his barber shop business.

loans.name: Fuatino

texts.en: Fuatino is 32 years old with four children. She operates a business selling banana and taro in her community to earn a living. She has been doing this for more than a year. Fuatino has requested a loan to buy banana tubes (seedlings), taro roots (seedlings), a wheelbarrow, water tank, hand gloves, shovel, chemicals, and a chainsaw to assist her to run the business. She joined SPBD in 2013 and hopes to use her business profit to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy banana tubes (seedlings), taro roots (seedlings), a wheelbarrow, water tank, hand gloves, shovel, chemicals, and a chainsaw

loans.name: Meripa

texts.en:
Meripa is a 45-year-old, married woman with six children. To earn a living, she runs a small canteen in her community. She has two years of experience with this business. 

Meripa needs a loan to buy sandwiches, pies, doughnuts, snacks, coffee, a large boiler, and soft drinks. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. 

Meripa has been a member of South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) since 2013.

loans.use: to buy sandwiches, pies, doughnuts, snacks, coffee, a large boiler, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy flour, cooking oil, sugar, milk, yeast, malagkit and coconut.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is 27 years old. She is married with three children.

Janeth has had two businesses; a salon as well as groceries/fruits store, which she has operated for seven years, earning a monthly income is KES 12,000. 

She has borrowed a loan of KES 24,000 which she will use to purchase hair extensions, hair oils, relaxers as well as shampoo for her salon. This is her second loan and she repaid her previous loan well.  

With the anticipated income, she will, be able to educate her children through high school.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to expand her business and educate her children well.

loans.use: to purchase hair extensions, hair oils, relaxers as well as shampoo for her salon

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is widowed with four children and they all go to school. She has no additional family members. She sells green bananas at the market seven days a week. She has been in this business for 20 years. She has applied for a loan from MCDT-SACCO to buy bunches of green bananas. She generates additional income through poultry farming. She sells both on retail and a wholesale basis. 

Her major business challenges include seasonality and transportation of food. Her future plan is to start growing green bananas. She resides in a rented house where the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy bunches of green bananas.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy sacks of Irish potatoes, cooking oil and charcoal for cooking.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 41 years old and she is married with six children. She has had a dairy farming business for 14 years. 

She will be using the loan to purchase quality dairy feeds, to feed. She hopes this will enable her cows to be more productive and hence make more milk sales so as to educate her children and expand her dairy farm. This is her 5th loan with VisionFund Kenya after successfully repaying her previous loans. 

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to educate her children through University level.

loans.use: to purchase quality dairy feed for her dairy cows.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 32 years old. He is married to Mercy, and they are not yet blessed with children. 

He has a mixed farming business, which he has run for four years. He currently earns a monthly income of KES 35,000.

Joseph has borrowed KES 60,000 from VisionFund Kenya as his third loan, after successfully repaying his previous loan.

He will be using the loan to purchase a sprinkler, overalls, gum boots, fertilizer, seedlings, animal feed and animal licks, and to build a milking ranch.He hopes the anticipated profit will help him buy food for the family, cater for the family’s medical care, pay for transportation of his farm products to the market, and repay his loan, too. 

His hopes and dreams for the future are to have a stable mixed farming business, secure more markets for his farm products, and enjoy a better life with his family.

loans.use: to purchase a sprinkler, overalls, gum boots, fertilizer, seedlings, animal feed and animal licks, and to build a milking ranch.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 49 years old. She is married with three children. 

She has had a dairy farming and fruit sale businesses for eight years. 

She has requested for her 6th loan with VisionFund Kenya which she will be using to purchase dairy feeds, and hopes this will help her educate her children. She successfully repaid her previous loans.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to educate her children to university level.

loans.use: to purchase dairy feeds

loans.name: Jedidah

texts.en:
Jedidah, 42 years old, is married to Nderitu, and they are blessed with four children aged 25, 20, 17 and 9 years old. She and her husband have managed their dairy for five years now and are currently earning a monthly income of 50,000 KES. 

Jedidah has borrowed 100,000 KES from VisionFund Kenya. This will be her first loan and will be used to buy a dairy cow and hay for their herd. With her profits she will be able to pay school fees for her children as well as develop the dairy further.

Jedidah’s hopes and dreams for the future are to have a well-developed dairy, provide a better education for her children and enjoy a better life with her family.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow and hay

loans.name: Hamisi

texts.en:
Hamisi is 35 years old. He is married to Susan and they are blessed with 4 children of ages between 14 and 1 year respectively.

Hamisi has had a farming business for 10 years earning a monthly income of KES 40,000. He borrowed KES 10,000 from VisionFund Kenya as his first loan in order to boost his business. And he will be using the loan to purchase timber logs for saw milling as well as animal feeds, sprinkler, pesticides, paracides and fertilizer. 

He hopes the anticipated profit will help him buy food for the family, pay school fees for his kids, cater for family medical care, pay for transportation of his farm products to the market and repay his loan too. 

His hopes and dream for the future is to benefit in his business so that he can take good care of his family.

loans.use: to purchase timber logs as well as animal feeds, sprinkler, pesticides, paracides and fertilizer

loans.name: Sandy Sandra

texts.es: La señora Sandra se dedica a la producción de leche cruda. Para ello, cuenta con 8 cabezas de ganado vacuno lechero y 3 cabezas de ganado vacuno terneras (9 meses). Desde muy pequeña, tuvo que trabajar para poder ayudar a sus hermanos en los gastos de la casa, ya que sus papás estaban en el extranjero. La Sra. Sandra tiene ahora 25 años de edad y gracias al trabajo con sus hermanos, ella cuenta con la experiencia necesaria para realizar su propia actividad. El motivo del presente crédito es para poder comprar cáscara de soya para su ganado vacuno lechero, ya que este insumo  es escaso y por ende de precio elevado. Actualmente, la solicitante está realizando el esfuerzo de comprar el insumo de un vendedor al por mayor que lo trae de otra ciudad, ya que sin este insumo la producción de su ganado bajaría considerablemente y esto perjudicaría a la Sra. Sandra tanto en sus ingresos como en la entrega de leche diaria.
texts.en:
The señora Sandra se dedica makes a live producing unpasteurized milk. For this business, she counts on eight dairy cows and three bull calves (9 months).

Since she was very young, Sandra had to work to help her sisters with the home expenses because her parents were abroad. Sandra is now 25 years old and thanks to working with her sisters, she has the experience necessary to run her own business.

The reason she is requesting this loan is to purchase soybean peels for her livestock because this feed is scarce and, therefore, expensive. Presently, Sandra is trying to buy the feed in bulk quantities from a vendor who brings it from another city. Without this feed, the production from her livestock will fall considerably and will endanger Sandra's earnings as there won't be enough milk each day.

loans.use: to purchase soybean peels for her dairy cattle because this feed is scarce and, therefore, it is expensive.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario owns and operates a variety store business to earn a living. She has been successful in this business for seven years and she repaid her previous loan used for the business. She also finds ways to improve her income by operating a tailoring business.

Relative to this, she would like to take a new loan to increase her product inventory. She is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy more quantities and varieties of grocery items and also raw materials like thread, needles, and other supplies she needs in her businesses.

In the future, she hopes that all her grandchildren will finish their studies and she wishes to improve the general living condition of her family. She is also looking forward to an improved grocery store and tailoring shop. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and there she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and also purchase more raw materials needed for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Flordeliz

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Flordeliz works hard to support her family. She earns a living by farming sugarcane in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from a general store. Flordeliz is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farm.

Flordeliz has been sustaining her business activities through her past 23 loans from NWTF and, more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farm.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
As a married parent of seven children, Nelly works hard to support her family.

She has a buy and sell of rice business in the Philippines and earns additional income from food vending.  Nelly is borrowing PHP 26,000 through NWTF to buy additional sacks of rice to sell. 

Nelly has been sustaining her business activities through her past 24 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of rice to sell for her business

loans.name: Azucena

texts.en:
Azucena is a married woman with four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Azucena is 41 years old and has three children who are in school.

She has a fish vending business in the Philippines. Azucena requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more seafood to sell.

She has been in this business for 20 years. In the future, Azucena would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more seafood to sell

loans.name: Orlina

texts.en:
Orlina is 38 years old and married with seven children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a charcoal "buy and sell" in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional charcoal to sell.

Orlina has borrowed and repaid 35 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the charcoal "buy and sell" for 10 years and also earns an income from motorcycle transport. She aspires to save enough money to be able to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional charcoal to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Josephine works hard to support her family. She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling charcoal.  Josephine is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy additional items like canned goods, charcoal, vegetables, chips, spices, etc. for her general store business.

Josephine has been sustaining her business activities through her past 22 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items like canned goods, charcoal, vegetables, chips, spices, etc.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
As a married mother of 11 children, Teresita works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from farming sugarcane. Teresita is borrowing PHP 30,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase more groceries to sell through her general store business.

Teresita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 28 loans from NWTF and, more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Yeremiah

texts.en: Yeremiah used the previous loan to buy general merchandise to sell. Yeremiah lives in Kasese, Uganda. He is a married man with five children. He operates a general merchandise shop and gets additional income from mobile money and a men's salon business. He has a dream of educating his children at a university, though he complains of the hardships of paying school fees on time for all the children. Yeremiya will use the loan to pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: to pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Meet Caroline, a youthful 28-year-old mother, and a wise farmer who neighbors and fellow farmers respect as a mentor. She farms a small plot of land in the green, lush hills of Kapsowar, in the Rift valley region of Kenya. Caroline is happily married, and together with her husband is blessed with a lovely family. 

For the past five years, she has been involved in mixed farming and her primary source of income has been growing maize, milk, cabbages, tomatoes and also she keeps dairy cows. Caroline has been able to provide nutritious food for her family. Although she has been making profits selling a variety of food crops, she is faced with a challenge of timely delivery of the produce to the market. This challenge has not made her give up; “I have to do something for my family,“ she said. Caroline mobilized other women in her village and joined Juhudi Kilimo, which is a microfinance institution that assists aspiring women like her. 

She is requesting a loan from Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva lenders to buy a motorbike. Caroline is from a remote village that has poor feeder roads and transporting her produce to the market has been a challenge, hence suffering so many losses. Perishable products such as milk, vegetables, and tomatoes require timely delivery to the market if you are to fetch a high price, and through this loan Caroline is going to achieve her dream and goals. Accessing a financial solution for women in Kenya is an uphill battle, but Caroline feels relieved to know that there are institutions such as Juhudi Kilimo via Kiva that help out women, so that they can gain respect and equality among their male counterparts. The benefits of this loan are astronomical, because Caroline will never suffer losses due to delays in delivery of produce to the market, and also she will increase her sales volume because she will be able to transport more goods to the market, hence an increased income level. Caroline is a woman who is making a change for herself and for others in the community, because she intends to employ someone who will be riding the motorbike and helping in farm work. With your loan, Caroline will improve her living conditions and assure her children of a secure future.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to deliver products to the market.

loans.name: Rael

texts.en:
Meet Rael from Kapsowar, Kenya, a community not known for farming, but she is earning a living through agriculture. She is happily married, and together with her husband, is blessed with a lovely and cute family. 

For the past five years, she has been practicing mixed farming, and, because of the experience she has, she commands a lot of respect from fellow farmers and is regarded as a mentor. Income from operating a green house, and selling milk, eggs, and maize has allowed her to earn a decent income. 
Rael passionately loves dairy farming, and animals on her farm have been given names. 

Rael has been actively engaged in mixed farming. She sells her farm’s produce at a local market near her home. Her in-depth knowledge of her environment has enabled Rael to get her hands on numerous small business opportunities. Rael is seeking a loan to purchase more poultry. She is very passionate about poultry farming. The most enjoyable task to her is raising poultry. Ironically, she doesn't enjoy feeding cows. Having additional poultry on her farm will bring her untold joy. The hens will also increase the farm's egg production, and thus, increase sales volume. Rael needs to increase her income to take care of her family's expenses. All that Rael waits for is your kindness.

loans.use: to pay for poultry

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
Trinidad is a hardworking, woman entrepreneur with six children. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell like chips, soap, shampoo, eggs, noodles, etc.

She industriously earns additional income through other business ventures like food vending. Trinidad dreams that one day she will be able to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell like chips, soap, shampoo, eggs, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Gado

texts.fr: Agée de 34 ans, Gado est une femme mariée et mère de deux enfants. Gado vit à Adidogomé pour exercer son activité de vente de chaussures.  Ce commerce lui permet de venir en aide aux besoins de sa famille et réaliser une bonne marge bénéficiaire. Gado s’approvisionne deux fois par mois au marché. Pour commander des chaussures, Gado demande ce prêt pour acheter son stock et avoir un bénéfice pour bien promouvoir à l’éducation de ses enfants
texts.en:
Gado is 34 years old and the mother of two children. She lives Adidogomé and sells shoes. Her business allows her to meet the needs of her family and earn a good profit margin.

Gado buys her supplies twice a month in the market. Gado is asking for this loan to buy shoes. This will help her buy stock and earn an income that will promote the education of her children.

loans.use: buy 125 pairs of shoes.

loans.name: Walma So Zia -Pishigu No.1 Group

texts.en:
Sanatu is a 40-year-old hardworking woman from Pishigu No.1 in the northern region of Ghana. Sanatu is married and has five children, four of them attending school. Safura is the individual pictured with her hand raised.

Sanatu is a member of a shea butter processing group that has been in business for the last 20 years. The name of the group is ‘Walma So Zia -Pishigu No.1’. Sanatu earns a good profit from the business as the group has been trained by Grameen Ghana on how to improve their shea butter processing business such that they can always produce premium quality for both the local and export markets.

Sanatu and ‘Walma So Zia -Pishigu No.1’ have asked for a loan of GHS 9,200. Sanatu’s share of the loan will help her to buy GHS 400 worth of shea nuts for processing. With this loan, Sanatu will earn more income, repay the loan and support her family to pay her children’s school fees.

Sanatu thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy shea nuts for processing.

loans.name: Khoirul

texts.en:
Good day, lenders! Now it’s time for you to meet one of the Ruma agents, Khoirul. Khoirul lives in Kudus, located east of Semarang, the capital of Central Java, a nine-hour hour drive from Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia. Khoirul is happily married. He owns a stall that sells mobile airtime credits for his community. He joined Ruma a year ago. He knew about Ruma from Ruma’s sales executive who came to his stall. He decided to join Ruma because he was interested in Ruma’s system; the sales executive comes to his stall to collect the money. Moreover, his community sees him as a trustworthy mobile provider.

As the business grows, Khoirul is hoping to get a working capital loan from Kiva. He will use the capital to process more mobile airtime credits and bill payment services to his communities. Having known about the importance, your loan will be very useful to help Khoirul improves his business and accordingly, his community, who needs access to such services. As seen in the photo, Khoirul is the one who is sitting in his stall. He will be very thankful for your kind support.

loans.use: to purchase additional prepaid airtime credit to sell to community members who want to use mobile phones to connect with loved ones.

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en: Kenneth, 27, is single young man working hard to provide for his future family and support his siblings. He rides a bodaboda (motorcycle taxi) as his major source of income. He also does trading of construction materials on a small scale to supplement his monthly income. He started business with high hopes of earning income to support his family. He has applied for a loan of 1,500,000 UGX to buy construction materials such a cement, nails and paint that he will sell.  His business is located in his local residence in Ishaka, western Uganda, and his clients are all types of people especially those building or planning to build. He is an honest man who works 11 hours a day and is faced with a challenge of poor roads and limited capital, but he is determined to grow his business through hard work. He hopes to become financially stable and complete his house that is still under construction. He appreciates kiva lenders through UGAFODE for helping him to expand his business and increase income avenues.

loans.use: to buy construction materials for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy materials for sewing into uniforms

loans.name: Amukeni Tabot Bee Keeping Self Help Group

texts.en:
The person raising his hand in the photo is Joseph, 54 years old, married and living with his wife and eight children. He is a member of Amukeni Tabot Bee Keeping Self Help Group and joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013.

He operates a motorbike business to earn an income. Enterprise and financial management provided by Hand in Hand Eastern Africa has enabled him to operate his business perfectly. He is borrowing a loan to purchase stock for his newly opened motorbike repair and spare parts business. This will enable him to meet his set goals of expanding the business with the increased income, thus supporting family needs and education for his children.

Joseph is grateful to Kiva and the lenders for this help and support and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy more stock of motorbike spare parts.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
The lady in the photo is Lydia, 33 years old, and blessed with two children. Lydia earns a living by selling clothes. She is happy for the Hand in Hand Eastern Africa enterprise training she received, which equipped her with skills to manage her business. 
 
The high demand in the market has made her apply for a loan to boost the business by adding more stock of clothes. This will increase her sales and income, which will enable her meet her objective of educating her children and provide for the family’s basic needs. Lydia is very grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promise to repay her loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes that will help boost her income from improved sales.

loans.name: Nakhaomin Group

texts.en:
Anusone understands the difference the water filter can make for her family and for her group’s families.  Anusone knows that local water sources require boiling before consumption and boiling water consumes natural and financial resources.  

The water filter Anusone purchased will increase her family’s disposable income by substantially decreasing money spent to buy charcoal or decreasing the time and cost foraging for firewood.  The filter also eliminates the need to purchase bottled water, if it is available.    

Anusone is excited that the filter was purchased on an affordable payment schedule and the filter is guaranteed for two years, so she and her group can continue to receive the many benefits of clean water for many months to come.

loans.use: to purchase TerraClear water filters, so she can have access to safe drinking water.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photo is Jacinta, 42 years old, married, and blessed with four children. Two of her children are currently attending school. She joined the Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2014 to benefit from enterprise development training.

She does poultry farming. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy more chicks, which will enable her in future, to increase production of eggs and chicken to earn more income to meet her family's basic needs like food and clothing. Jacinta is grateful to Kiva for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy more chicks to increase production of eggs and chicken, to earn more income to meet her family's basic needs like food and clothing.

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Djènèba  est la cliente qui tient les cornes du bélier en main.
Agée de trente-sept ans (37 ans), Djènèba est une emboucheuse malienne des ovins. Mariée, mère de quatre(04) enfants dont un (01) scolarisé  (Second cycle de l’enseignement fondamentale). Djènèba rêve dans les jours de payer une moto pour ses enfants. Elle n’a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école mais elle a fréquenté le centre d’alphabétisation du village pendant trois (03) ans. Elle se défend beaucoup dans son activité. Djènèba a fait recourt au RMCR pour achéter beaucoup de béliers. Elle fait ses achats (béliers) dans la foire hebdomadaire de sa zone. Avec son prêt de 125 000FCFA , elle  achète trois (03) têtes de béliers à cent dix mille francs (110 000 F CFA) et les quinze mille francs (15 000 F CFA) sont utilisés pour l’achat des aliments bétails et les soins vétérinaires. Djènèba engraisse ses béliers, les soigne et les revend à la  même foire hebdomadaire de sa zone. Elle fait des bénéfices variant entre cinquante mille (50 000 FCFA)   à cinquante-cinq mille francs (55 000 FCFA) par cycle de prêt. Djènèba fait l’embouche des ovins depuis plus de douze (12 ans). Elle ne se plaint pas pour le déroulement de son activité mais souvent certains béliers crèvent.

NB:le montant du groupe est correcte, 2 155 000FCFA.
Les 125 000FCfa appartient à Djènèba seule.
texts.en:
Djènèba is the client who is holding onto the ram's horns [in the photo]. Djènèba is 37 years old and is a Malian ovine farmer who is married and the mother of four children, one of whom attends school (second cycle of basic education[, i.e. high school]). Djènèba daydreams of purchasing a motorbike for her children. She did not have the opportunity to attend school but did visit the village's literacy center for three years.

Djènèba largely fends for herself in her business. She has turned to RMCR to purchase many rams. She makes her purchases (rams) at the weekly bazaar in her area. With her loan of 125,000 CFA francs, she will purchase three rams for 110,000 CFA francs, and the [remaining] 15,000 CFA francs will be used for livestock feed and veterinary care.

Djènèba raises her rams, cares for them, and resells them at the same weekly local bazaar. Her profits range from 50,000 to 55,000 CFA francs per loan cycle. Djènèba has been raising ovines for more than 12 years. She doesn't ask for sympathy with the operation of her business, but some rams often die.

NB: While the group loan is for 2,155,000 CFA francs, Djènèba's portion of the loan is only 125,000 CFA francs.

loans.use: To purchase rams to sell after having raised them.

loans.name: Maseno Self Help Group

texts.en:
Joyce, raising her hand in the photograph, is a member of Maseno Self Help Group. She is 48 years old. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to benefit from training courses on enterprise development and financial management. She farms tomatoes and maize.

She is taking a Kiva loan to purchase farm inputs, such as sacks and fertilizer. She hopes this will improve the crop yield and generate more income to meet her family's needs.

Joyce is grateful for the Kiva loan and promises to make the established payments.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs, such as sacks and fertilizer, to improve on crop productivity.

loans.name: Tiresa

texts.en: Tiresa is a 42-year-old, mother with four children. She runs and operates a small convenience store in her village to earn a living. Tiresa need a loan to buy a freezer, box of chicken, sack of sugar, sack of rice, box of tinned fish, box of vegetable oil, box of milk, and plastic bags to assist her in running the business. She has been doing this for more than three years. Tiresa became a member of SPBD in 2011.

loans.use: to buy a freezer, box of chicken, sack of sugar, sack of rice, box of tinned fish, box of vegetable oil, box of milk, and plastic bags.

loans.name: Flocerfida

texts.en:
Flocerfida previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profits. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Aside from her variety store, Flocerfida also operate a rental house. She aims to have more space, which she could also use for business, and she dreams to help and provide for her grandchildren. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is a single mother of three children and all of her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (mother and niece). She has a business of making envelopes for photographs and drugs. She has been in this business for 15 years. She doesn’t have any other income-generating activities. She has applied for a loan of UGX 3,000,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy rolls of papers and glue. She works from her home seven days a week and sells on both a wholesale and retail basis. Her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She is aspiring to start training other people so as to get more labor and production. She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: to buy rolls of paper and glue

loans.name: Juber Antonio

texts.es: Don Juber de 58 años de edad vive en casa propia con su grupo familiar, el se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz y ajonjolí, posee 21 años de dedicarse a esa actividad la cual inicio con capital propio, adicional a eso también se dedica al transporte de personal, con lo que obtiene de su trabajo logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, el esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, abonos, herbicidas, entre otras cosas y mejorar el terreno que muestra la fotografía para poder continuar con sus ventas y así tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Juber is 58 years old. He lives in his own home with his household.
 
He is dedicated to growing corn and sesame. He has 21 years of experience in that activity which he began with his own capital. In addition to that he also works transporting personnel. With his earnings he can meet some of the household expenses. 

He is asking for a loan to buy seed, fertilizer, compost, herbicides, and other items to improve the land shown in the photograph in order to continue with his sales and thus have higher income.

loans.use: to buy seed, fertilizer, compost, and herbicides among other items and improve the land

loans.name: Nsoborwa Tweimukye Group

texts.en:
Molly is a 52-year-old, who has four children aged 25, 20, 18 and 10. Molly is a farmer who grows crops like maize and rice, but she also operates a bar and sells cereals to boost her income.

She has applied for a loan of UGX 1,500,000 through her group of Nsoborwa. She wants the loan to buy farm inputs such as fertilizers and improved seeds in order to improve her farming activities, and also to educate her children.

Her dream for the future is to build a good house for her family. She is hardworking and honest and thanks the group members for standing by her side to help her grow financially. The group thanks Kiva lenders for the job well done.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs.

loans.name: Sokol

texts.en:
Sokol is 43 and a father to three children ranging in age from four to eight years old. They are members of the vulnerable ethnic minority known as Egyptian Albanians, and they live in the city of Elbasan.  Sokol was the only member of his family of five who was making an income until his wife started doing recycling.

Sokol has been doing transportation of goods and people for the past 10 years. “Many members of my community do this type of activity. Usually, we are seen waiting for work next to major road intersection. We transport almost anything, from people to materials, recycled scrap and goods,” said Sokol to his loan officer.

Sokol will use this loan to repair the vehicle that he uses as a means to earn income to support his family.

loans.use: to repair the vehicle that he uses as a means to earn income to support his family.

loans.name: Alba Dori

texts.es:
Alba una dama que se dedica a las confecciones desde el año 2009, es madre de dos hijas de 9 y 4 años de edad, su profesión la inicio por gusto al trabajo independiente, aprendió a usar máquinas de confeccionar ya que tomo clases pues tenía muy claro que iba a montar un negocio y que este iba a ser el que le diera de comer de ahora en adelante y hoy año 2015 ha cumplido con sus palabras.

El sueño de Alba es tener su propia marca, pero pasa algo asombroso y es que tú puedes ser partícipe del cumplimiento de este sueño apoyándola con un préstamo el cual ella destinara a la compra de una troqueladora y telas, con estos dos productos podrá dar los primeros pasos de confección de su línea propia se siente muy emocionada y agradece a todo aquel que leyó su historia, se compromete a progresar y sacar su negocio adelante.
texts.en:
Alba is a lady who has worked in apparel since 2009. She is the mother of two daughters, ages 9 and 4. She started working in this profession in order to be able to do freelance work. After she learned to use sewing machines, it became clear that she was going to start a business that would be her bread-and-butter from then on. Now, in 2015, this has proven to be the case.

Alba's dream is to have her own brand. The amazing part is that you can be part of this dream by supporting it with a loan, the proceeds of which will be used to buy a die cutting machine and fabric. With these two products, she can take the first steps to making her own line. She feels very excited and grateful to everyone who reads her story. She is committed to progress and take her business forward.

loans.use: buy a die cutting machine and fabric to realize her dream of starting her own clothing line.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Elvira works hard to support her family. She has a buy-and-sell rice business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening. She is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy additional rice to sell for her buy-and-sell rice business.

Elvira has been sustaining her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional rice to sell.

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia is 55 years old and married with four children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock of household goods to sell.

Nelia has borrowed and repaid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for eight years and also earns an income from selling rice.

She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of household goods to sell

loans.name: Soet Women Group

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand in the photograph is Penina, a member of Soet Women Group in Nakuru Kenya. She is married and a mother of four children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in April 2013.

Penina does maize, beans and dairy farming. She is grateful to HiH EA for enterprise training and inculcating in her a culture of saving. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to purchase a dairy goat to help improve her milk production that will help satisfy customers' demand for goat milk and hence earn more income from her dairy enterprise.  She will thus be in a position to cater to her family's needs such as food and save for the future.

Penina is grateful to Kiva and its lenders for their support. She promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy a dairy goat that will help boost milk production.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
The lady in the photo is Grace. She is 38 years old, married, and blessed with five children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in 2013.

Grace does maize, bean, and dairy farming. She has benefited from the HiH EA enterprise and financial development training and has acquired skills that help her to run and manage her business well.

She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy fertilizer and seeds that will help increase the quantity and quality of her yields and thus maximize her profit. Income from this enterprise will help take care of family basic needs, education and medical care.

Grace is grateful to Kiva and its lenders and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds to help increase crop yield.

loans.name: Filiga

texts.en: Filiga is a 41-year-old, married woman with four children. She runs a small canteen in her community to earn a living. She has four years of experience with this business. Filiga needs a loan to buy drinks, snacks, napkins, plastic forks, paper plates and a cooler. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses, and also to help with the development of her business. Filiga has been a member of SPBD since 2011.

loans.use: to buy drinks, snacks, napkins, plastic forks, paper plates and a cooler.

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en: Michelle is a 21-year-old, mother with two children. She runs a small business of selling tuna sandwiches, and toasted sandwiches in her community to earn a living. She has been doing this for more than a year. Michelle need a loan to buy bread, tomato sauce, a box of canned tuna fish, plastic bags, a container, and butter to assist with the business. She will expand her business using her profits. Michelle became a member of SPBD in 2015.

loans.use: to buy bread, tomato sauce, a box of  canned tuna fish, plastic bags, a container, and butter.

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Zaituni lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with four children and all go to school. She has no additional family members. She sells charcoal at the market on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 20 years. 

Zaituni works seven days a week. She earns additional income from providing outside catering services. She has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from MCDT – SACCO to buy bags of charcoal. Her major challenges include seasonality and transportation. Her goal and aspiration is to build rental houses.

Zaituni lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en:
Ligaya is 62 years old and married with seven children. She works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 27,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, soap, chips, bread, soft drinks, etc.

Ligaya has been in this business for 10 years.

In the future, Ligaya would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, soap, chips, bread, and soft drinks

loans.name: Alvaro Antonio

texts.es:
Él es Álvaro una persona muy querida en el barrio san diego, él tiene una chaza de venta de dulces, papas en bolsa, tintos, perico (café con leche), gaseosas, cigarrillos, gomas de mascar etc., tiene su negocio por que le gusta el trabajo independiente le saca la utilidad para el sostenimiento de su hogar que lo conforma sus tres hijas de 17, 15, 12 años de edad, y su pareja, 4 mujeres que en la medida de lo posible trata consentirlas y darles todo lo que este a su alcance.

Lo que más caracteriza a Álvaro es su sonrisa y la forma como trata a sus clientes, tanto así que lo tratan como un miembro más de la familia y él se siente feliz de realizar esta profesión por el ambiente que lo rodea por ello se empeña mucho en no perderla.

Su sueño es juntar capital para comprar una vivienda cerca de su sitio de trabajo.

Solicita un préstamo para la compra de surtido de cigarrillos, café, bebidas y papas en bolsa
texts.en:
He is Alvaro, a much-loved person in the San Diego neighbourhood. 

He has a mobile kiosk for selling candy, potato chips, black coffee, coffee with milk, sodas, cigarettes, chewing gum, and the like. He has this business because he likes to be self-employed, and he generates the income to support his family, which is composed of his partner and their three daughters—aged 17, 15, and 12. He does the best he can to pamper these four women and give them everything within his means.

Alvaro is well known for his smile and the way he treats his customers. They even treat him as a member of their families, and he is happy to be following this occupation because of the friendly atmosphere that surrounds him. For this reason, he works hard to stay in business.

His dream is to save enough money to buy a house close to his place of work.

He is requesting a loan to buy an assortment of products such as cigarettes, coffee, beverages, and potato chips.

loans.use: to buy an assortment of products such as coffee, beverages, potato chips and cigarettes.

loans.name: Ancheta

texts.en:
Ancheta is a hardworking, entrepreneur who has a buy-and-sell vegetable business in the Philippines.  She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy additional vegetables to sell for her buy-and-sell vegetable business.

Ancheta has been in this business for 15 years. She also earns more income from food vending. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Rafael Ángel

texts.es:
Rafael es un hombre de 56 años de edad, es casado, no tiene hijos, en la época del año 2013 se quedó desempleado, estaba buscando donde trabajar pero debido a su edad le cerraraón muchas puertas, Rafael nos e rindió y comentaba su situación con los amigos, uno de ellos tendero de casi toda la vida le sugirió que montara una tienda de barrio de venta de productos de la canasta familiar, a Rafael le sonó la idea y hoy en día es el negocio que le da de comer a él y su esposa.

Ahora Rafael trabaja por mejorar su estilo de vida, solo pide tener salud para trabajar, todo lo demás lo quiere hacer él, si le va bien y la utilidad es buena quiere reformar su casa volverla más lujosa, su único deseo es vivir una vida tranquila junto a su esposa.

Rafael busca abastecer su negocio, pero no cuenta con el capital, por ello quiere solicitar un préstamo y busca que lo apoyen para comprar surtido de arroz, frijoles, sopas instantáneas, atún, panela, aceite de cocina, mantequilla, papa, gaseosas, papas en bolsa, cigarrillos, productos de aseo.

Este préstamo le permitirá a Rafael tener un surtido muy amplio para que sus clientes encuentren todo en su tienda y sus ventas mejoren considerablemente.
texts.en:
Rafael is 56-years-old and married with no children. In 2013 he was left unemployed. He looked for work but found his age to be an obstacle. Rafael gave up and told friends about the situation. One of them, a shopkeeper most of his life, suggested opening a neighborhood store selling basic family products. The idea resonated with Rafael and today this is the business that puts food on the table for Rafael and his wife.

Now Rafael works to improve their lifestyle. He only asks to be healthy so he is able to work. Everything else he is wants to do for himself. If he does well and remains in good health, he wants to renovate their home to make it more luxurious. His only desire is to live a quiet life with his wife.

Rafael wants to supply his business but he doesn't have the capital. For this reason he is requesting a loan for assistance buying an assortment of rice, beans, instant soups, tuna, brown sugar, cooking oil, butter, potatoes, soft drinks, potato chips, cigarettes and toiletries.

This loan will allow Rafael to have a wide assortment of products for his clients. They will find everything in his store and his sales will improve considerably.

loans.use: buy rice, beans, instant soups, tuna, brown sugar, cooking oil, butter, potatoes, soft drinks, potato chips, cigarettes and toiletries.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 37 years old and married with two children.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Marilyn is borrowing PHP 11,000 through NWTF to pay laborers' salaries during the rice harvest.

Marilyn has been farminig rice for five years and also earns additional income from selling vegetables.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to pay laborers' salaries during the rice harvest

loans.name: Sidorela

texts.en:
This is Sidorela, a 19-year-old, married mother and a villager, who has been photographed inside the so-called house with her adorable 1-year-old daughter. Kindly note, that they live very poorly in a room that they have built themselves with some concrete blocks and covered with sheet metal. There is no tile flooring or electricity, no toilet or running water. 

“It has been extremely cold this past winter and especially for my daughter. There was no way we could warm up or cook. I cannot describe how lamentably we have been living here…” said Sidorela wiping away during the interview inside the cabin or the one-room thing where she wants to do some work.  Sidorela is almost begging lenders to help her financially.

loans.use: to make livable, the cabin they've been living in this past year.

loans.name: Ndungiri Muthingi Water Women Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Jane, fifty years old and blessed with five children. All her children are in secondary school. Jane is married and lives with her five children. 

She runs a poultry enterprise. She is borrowing from Kiva to purchase chicken feed to boost her poultry business.  She hopes the loan will increase her sales and hence increase her level of income. This will enable her to be in a position to provide food and pay school fees for her children. 

Jane is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the financial support and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed to boost her poultry business by improving productivity.

loans.name: Kabuswa Moricho Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Rose, a member of Kabuswo Moricho group. Rose is 51 years old, married, and has seven children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013.  She does banana, maize and bean farming to earn a living. She has learned and gained more experience in enterprise start up and development and financial management, which have helped her manage her finances well.  

She is borrowing a loan to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizers and quality hybrid seeds. This will enable her increase the crop yield, hence improve her income, and thus be in a position to educate her children. Rose is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the help and support. She promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as fertilizer and hybrid seeds to improve on crop yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cereals for resale.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is a 33-year-old, married woman with five children. She runs a small canteen in her community to earn a living. She has three years of experience with this business. Stella needs a loan to buy a small cooler, an oven, a crate of soft drinks, snacks, plastic plates and forks. She plans to use her profits to support her family financially. Stella has been a member of SPBD since 2012.

loans.use: to buy a small cooler, an oven, a crate of soft drinks, snacks, plastic plates and forks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cassava polenta and kékéliba

loans.name: Tujikwamue Ukonga Group

texts.en:
Florencee, who is in his early 40s, is married with four children. Two of them are at school and two of them are still small.  He has been running a business for 12 years of buying meat at the slaughtering place and delivering it to different butcher shops.  He works from 02am to 05am daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Florencee's tenth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the previous loans to keep on increasing the meat stock, and has paid back all his loans successfully.  He is happy with the loan and appreciates Kiva for their support.  

He used the profit to pay school fees, loan repayment, build his own house, bought a TV set, a radio, cupboards and covered household expenses.  

He will use this loan to increase on the meat stock and serve more customers.  He dreams of building another house.  

Florencee will share this loan with his loan group, Tujikwamue Ukonga, which consist of four members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to increase the meat stock and serve more customers.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
This is Elsa. She is 51 years old and currently resides with her husband, Remy, in Taguig City, Philippines. She has been operating her own “sari-sari” (variety) store for more than three years, and she profits well from this. Having a bigger responsibility requires more effort to provide for her family's needs. She and her partner are working hard and they are determined to have a better income.

In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She also offers frozen food products like homemade sausages, hotdogs and other like produce. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To improve sales, Elsa would like to apply for a loan to purchase additional grocery goods to sell. At an amount of 10,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos), she could already purchase larger quantities and more varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. She sincerely lets you know her heartfelt thanks and appreciation for this assistance in advance.

In the future, Elsa hopes to maintain an increasing profit from her business. At the same time, she wants to have her own stall someday. She dreams for her family to be always happy and healthy. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God, which she studies.

*All CCT (Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase larger quantities and more varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is 47 years old and married with nine children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell like soap, milk, chips, noodles, canned goods, etc.

Imelda has borrowed and repaid 15 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for four years and also earns an income from poultry. She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell like soap, milk, chips, noodles, canned goods, etc.

loans.name: Linah

texts.en:
Linah is a good, happy, sharing, loving, and faithful person and a hard-working mum. She is from Kapsowar, a remote town in the Rift Valley province of Kenya. She has spent the past 10 years of her life farming. She sells milk, maize, and vegetables produced on her farm. She also engages in personal business, to make ends meet. 

Linah is a go-getter and has a great desire to succeed in life. Of all the activities she involves herself in, dairy farming is closest to her heart. She enjoys waking up every morning to go and milk her cows and feed them with fodder that has high nutrient value. She is so keen on and close to her cows, she has named one of them. Milking her cows makes Linah very proud, and she feels fulfilled. 

Dairy farming being a very profitable business venture, Linah wants to take full advantage. She would like to expand her dairy business, but the biggest challenge she faces is a lack of capital for growth. She is requesting a loan which she will use to buy a quality breed of dairy cow. Linah has planted Napier grass, so feeding the cows will never be a challenge. She also owns an expansive piece of land, and the excess space will be productively used once she acquires the additional dairy cow. 

The exotic cow she will buy will produce between 10 and 15 litres of milk per day, and this will translate to more income and profits. The profits from milk selling will allow Linah to grow her business further, by starting to package milk and by processing it into other dairy products such as cream. In addition, she will benefit from the organic manure from the cow. She projects that in the future she will be able to start a biogas plant at her farm, which will save her money in fuel costs. With your loan, all that Linah dreams of is a secure future for her children.

Linah awaits your kindness.

loans.use: to buy an exotic, high-quality dairy cow

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Hello world! Meet Fredrick, an educated and seasoned 65 year old farmer from Kanyakine village in the Nkubu area of Kenya. Fredrick is married to a lovely wife. They have been married for 35 years and blessed with 3 children.

Fredrick started farming 30 years ago. On his 3.5 acre farm, he keeps 3 dairy cows, 30 head of poultry, 3 goats and several sheep. In terms of plants, he has over 30 trees and a garden that contains maize, bananas and coffee.

Fredrick is very disciplined: He always records expenses, updates his budget every month, and is concerned about human activities that are responsible for climate change. Fredrick is seeking a KES 80,000 loan from Kiva lenders that will change the way he conducts his business forever. He will use the money to buy a chaff cutter and feed for his animals. The chaff cutter will be used to chop hay into small even sizes that his cow will enjoy to chew. He will further buy the best feed from agro-vets which contain nutrients and minerals necessary for body growth in cows and high milk production.

Fredrick has a good history with Juhudi Kilimo which advanced him a previous loan of KES 40,000. He also has high savings with the company which reflects his outstanding financial literacy. A loan to Fredrick will have a great impact on his business and his family's well-being as well.

loans.use: to buy a chaff cutter and feed for his animals.

loans.name: Yesica Yohana

texts.es:
Yesica es una bella mujer de 30 años de edad ella vive en la zona de mariquita Antioquia, es una mujer humilde pero muy recursiva, vende alimentos como almuerzos, pasa bocas, desayunos y en el patio de su casa tiene ubicado una zona de diversión de un juego muy colombiano llamado tejo, juego que lo disfrutan mucho los mayores de edad, tomando cerveza y compartiendo.

En la foto podemos observar la cancha de tejo, ella decidió empezar esta actividad buscando comprar la vivienda donde hoy vive ya que en esta ha pasado momentos muy espaciales, en conclusión su objetivo principal es comprar la vivienda para dejar de pagar arriendo.

Yesica quiere solicitar un préstamo para comprar surtido del productos más vendido en su tienda que es la cerveza, ya que en una buena partida de tejo pueden consumir entre 10 y 15 cervezas.
texts.en:
Yesica is a beautiful woman who is 30 years old. She lives in the Mariquita Antioquia area. She is a humble and very reserved woman. She sells food such as lunches, snacks, breakfasts and in the patio of her house she has an area to enjoy the Colombian game called tejo, a game that is enjoyed a lot by adults, drinking beer while partaking.

In the photo we can see the tejo court. She decided to begin this activity looking for a way to buy the house where she lives as she has spent some special moments there. In conclusion her main objective is to buy the house in order to stop paying rent.

Yesica wants a loan in order to buy the products most sold in her store which is beer since during a good game of tejo 10 to 15 beers can be consumed.

loans.use: to buy a wide range of beer to sell while people play the Colombian game called tejo on the tejo court she has in her patio

loans.name: Gagik

texts.en:
Gagik is a musician who lives in Armavir, Armenia, with his mother, grandmother and brother (who is also musician). 

Gagik has participated in many singing contests and is a very talented singer. 

To be able to pay for his video clip recording and develop his career as a singer, Gagik has applied for this loan. 

He has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The loan program provides start-up loans with soft conditions to businesses that do not have access to traditional credit products. 

Gagik hopes for your support to develop his career and become a successful singer.

loans.use: to pay for his video clip recording and develop his career as a singer.

loans.name: Joseline

texts.en:
Joseline is a single mother of three children. Joseline lives in the outskirts of Lyantonde, where she runs a small restaurant to earn income to meet her family needs.

She is borrowing UGX 3,000,000 to be able to boost her business through buying food, warmers and other utensils in order to serve her customers better. She appreciates the fact the Kiva lenders love to partner with the rural poor. She is resilient and looks forward to paying her loan well to maintain the partnership.

loans.use: To buy food and warmers for the restaurant.

loans.name: Bethesda S.h.g Group

texts.en:
The person raising his hand in the photograph is called Kikubi; a member of Bethesda S.H.G Group. He is aged 77 years, married and blessed with 3 children. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA )in 2012 to benefit from their training, especially on savings mobilization and enterprise development.

Kikubi is a poultry farmer and is requesting a Kiva loan to buy more indigenous chicken thus increasing production of chickens and eggs for sale in order to satisfy the rising market for them.

He is thankful to Kiva for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy more indigenous chicken in order to increase production of chickens and eggs to satisfy the rising market  for them.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Nicholas, who is 42 years old, married and has one child. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to learn more about business and also to improve his living standards. 

Nicholas is a farmer who keeps goats for dairy purposes. He is borrowing a loan to buy more goats to help increase his income. This will help him meet the family's needs with ease.

He is happy for Kiva for their support.

loans.use: to buy more dairy goats that will help boost milk production.

loans.name: Laouratou

texts.fr: Agée de 43 ans, Laouratou est une femme veuve et vit à Agoè avec ses sept enfants. Pour contribuer aux besoins quotidiens de la famille, Laouratou vend des condiments dans son quartier. Laouratou s’approvisionne une fois par mois au marché local. Laouratou demande ce crédit pour acheter des épices afin de disposer d’un stock nécessaire pour satisfaire ses clients et réaliser une bonne marge bénéficiaire et favoriser l’éducation de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Aged 43, Laouratou is a widow and lives in Agoè with her seven children. In order to contribute to the needs of her family, Laouratou sells condiments in her neighborhood. She stocks up once a month in a local market. 

Laouratou is asking for this loan to buy some spices so as to have the necessary stock to satisfy the needs of her clients and make a good profit margin and support the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy some spices.

loans.name: Hinxieu Group

texts.en:
TaDam’s village sources much of its drinking water from local wells, streams and collected rainwater.  Unfortunately, the water collected from these sources is not safe to drink without treating it through boiling. 

TaDam and her group are excited that the TerraClear water filter was available on a payment plan, which made it much more affordable.  

Treating drinking water requires cash and time, both of which TaDam can now spend on other pursuits.  

TaDam and her village also understand the impact that unsafe drinking water has on their family’s budgets. 

The filter is guaranteed for two years. Within this time period, filter users such as TaDam’s family will enjoy a substantial decrease in illnesses and the associated medical costs.

loans.use: to purchase TerraClear water filters so they can have access to safe drinking water.

loans.name: Mamavi

texts.fr: A 43 ans, Mamavi est une femme veuve et mère de deux enfants. Mamavi habite à Agoè pour répondre à ses besoins. Pour trouver son  revenu, Mamavi vend des légumes dans le quartier. Mamavi s’approvisionne trois fois par mois au marché. Mamavi nécessite ce crédit pour acheter des légumes afin de gagner assez de bénéfices et venir en aide à l’éducation scolaire de ses enfants
texts.en:
Aged 43,  Mamavi is a widow and mother of two children. She lives in Agoè so that she can meet her needs. To earn her living, Mamavi sells vegetables in the neighborhood. She stocks up three times a month in the market. 

Mamavi needs this loan to buy vegetables so that she can earn enough profit and help cover the school fees of her children.

loans.use: to buy a pile of vegetables.

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
The person in this photo is Andrew, who is 38 years old and married. He is blessed with eight children. He sells foodstuffs and charcoal in a kiosk. He has received hands-on training on enterprise and financial management, which has improved his business through proper record-keeping and prudent financial management. 

Andrew is borrowing a Kiva loan to expand his kiosk by buying more stock of foodstuffs. This will lead to more sales and thus more income. This will ensure that he continues supporting his family. Andrew appreciates Kiva for the support, and he promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy more stock of foodstuffs to boost his profits.

loans.name: Toaganamua

texts.en:
for the past year Toaganamua, 24 years old, has been running a business selling elei printing at the market to earn a living. .A loan amount of $1500ST will help her to buy rolling material, paint brushes, paint color, containers, designs and a printing machine to help run the business.  

Toaganamua became a member of SPBD in 2014. She will use her profits to support her family.

loans.use: to buy rolling material, paint brushes, paint color, containers, designs and a printing machine

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 55 years old and chose to be single. She lives in a rural community and manages a small retail store in her area. She aspires to improve this business and increase her income in order to cover the costs of her necessities, support her nieces and nephews, and save some for her future. Due to capital insufficiency, she would to access an additional loan of 8,000 PHP to buy grocery items, including rice, seasonings, eggs, soft drinks, cooking oils, and dried fish to resell. She is hoping that this financial assistance will enable her to improve the business.

loans.use: to buy grocery items, including rice, seasonings, eggs, soft drinks, cooking oils, and dried fish to resell

location.town: Brgy. Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Melca

texts.en:
MelcaMelca, who is married, works hard to support her family. She has been operating a fishing business in the Philippines for 19 years now. 

Melca has requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to purchase a fishing net, gasoline, bamboo, etc. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing net, gasoline, bamboo, etc

loans.name: Bridget

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Bridget works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs. Bridget is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to purchase an additional bundle of fishing net for her fishing business.

Bridget  has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase an additional bundle of fishing net

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase poultry

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Hello world, meet Rhoda. A smallholder farmer from Ndaragwa, Kenya, Rhoda is the mother of two children.
